Identification of web service accounts o.Action: Ingest and correlate external threat intelligence feeds containing indicators (e.g., email addresses used for registration, associated IPs/domains) linked to known threat actor use of legitimate web services for resource development. Query intelligence platform for matches.

Network traffic from internal systems co.Action: Monitor Zeek conn.log and http.log for connections originating from internal systems to known malicious domains or IP addresses hosted on legitimate web services (e.g., GitHub, Google Drive, Pastebin) identified via threat intelligence. Analyze connection patterns, frequency, and payload characteristics (if available) using descriptive statistics and time series analysis to identify unusual communications.

Internal web browsing activity related t.Action: Filter Zeek http.log for visits from internal systems to known legitimate web service domains (e.g., *.github.com, *.drive.google.com, *.twitter.com, *.pastebin.com). Analyze requested URLs for patterns indicative of account registration, repository creation, or sensitive data uploads (e.g., paths like /join, /signup, /new, /create, or specific API endpoints). Use frequency analysis or outlier detection (e.g., IQR or percentiles on URL path lengths, number of unique domains visited) to identify unusual browsing patterns by internal users to these services.

Outbound network connections from intern.Data: Zeek conn.log; Zeek http.log; Zeek dns.log
Outbound network connections from intern.Action: Monitor Zeek dns.log and conn.log for internal hosts resolving or connecting to domains/subdomains hosted on legitimate services (e.g., *.github.io, *.googleusercontent.com, *.readthedocs.io) that are newly observed in the environment, have low DNS reputation scores (if available), or are flagged by threat intelligence. Correlate with Zeek http.log to inspect request patterns and transferred bytes. Use time series analysis to identify initial, low-volume connections from internal hosts to these potentially suspicious destinations hosted on web services, as this could indicate testing activity.
